node.doctext:
CST review archive 10

This is a storage node for CST reviews. Contents are moved her from [CST_Chat].

This archive begins on 01/27/04, ends 02/24/04. When it's full we'll move to[CST_Storage_11].

See also Quest Storage collabs [CST_Storage_1|1], [CST_Storage_2|2], [CST_Storage_3|3], [CST_Storage_4|4], [CST_Storage_5|5], [CST_Storage_6|6], [CST_Storage_7|7], [CST_Storage_8|8], [CST_Storage_9|9].

24 February 2004

Writeup Title:[A Supermarket in California]
Author:[Lometa]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: N
Original Author's Permission received?: N
Quoted content less than 33%: Y
Compliance Assessment: Y
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2004.2.18 (1.5 hr) momomom says (r) 2004.2.18@18:25 $ (1.2 min) Lometa says Would it be A Supermarket in California ? Each set of quotes is taken from separate sources so the math is done for each quote.

Q:  If a writeup uses multimple quotes, from multimple sources, how do I do the compliance word counts?

A Each unique source is treated independently. It gets it's own 250 word limit and is separately counted for 2/3 calculations against the total writeup word count.

Analysis

Why evaluate the quotes independently? The first time this came up, [dem_bones] had me get a ruling from [Apatrix] who said, "Different (copyright) registration, different work." i.e. evaluate each quoted work independently. Frankly, I'm not overly confident of [Apatrix]'s legal expertise, but this interpretation makes sense if you consider the artful selection of illustrative quotes to be a legitimate form of artistic expression by the noder. Obviously this could be abused, but E2 Editors have the right to nuke a writeup like that even if it is technically compliant.

A Contrived but Illustrative Example 

"This is a 10  word Quote: by author number 1."  "This is a 10  word Quote: by author number 2." "This is a 10  word Quote: by author number 3."

This is a 19 word segment of original explication text. This paragraph is a 19 word segment of explication.

In evaluating the  Author 1 Quote:

- The Total Wordcount (explication plus the other quotes) equals 49 words, so for the 2/3 calculation you get 10 / 49 = 20% The writeup is compliant under fair use

 

[arieh] says: ... Way I see it, only things that matter are "No of cited words total" and "no of original words, total...formulae suggested below are open to abuse. In Ex1, if there were 100 quotes like quote5, the wu would pass anyway.
[gom] said "Good point, that's why Lo's wu is such a fine example. "Lo's artful selection of quotes to illustrate her discussion of the poem is, in itself, a legit artistic expression and thus "original content" at least in some sense. This could be abused, but I think we need to err on the noder's side ->" to arieh

Batch added 03/10/2004 -gom

Writeup Title:[The Big Rock Candy Mountain]
Author:[spiregrain]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: Yes.
Original Author's Permission received?: N/A
Quoted content less than 33%:N/A
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:[spiregrain] says [Chiisuta] alerted me to this: [The Big Rock Candy Mountain]. I understand it to be public domain. What do I do to get hold of one of these here "tags"?
User messaged, "Hello spiregrain I hope you don’t mind that I did a little research on this song and added an editor’s note. You can leave it as is or incorporate in into the write up if you would like to. It passed with flying colors and you can add the [CST Approved] tag. Thanks!"

2004.02.21 at 15:02 Lometa says I've messaged [Freddo] about his [The 9 Horse |Bukowski] poem.
March 6, 2004. No reply from Freddo about updating. User messaged. “re: [The 9 Horse] I’m sorry to say that we can no longer retain copyrighted work on E2 . If you would like to resubmit the poem please refer to [E2 copyright changes]. Please feel free to message me if you have any questions. [Lometa|Lo]“

Writeup Title:[Michael Moore's Oscar acceptance speech]
Author:[spikeofsilver]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Y
Original Author's Permission received?: NA
Quoted content less than 33%: NA
Compliance Assessment: Y
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:2004.2.19 [Lometa] says A question for consideration. Since it probably wasn't scripted would [Michael Moore's Oscar acceptance speech] be copyrighted to the program that aired it or is it exempt because it is public discourse?
Per the Content_Salvage FAQ: "Quotes from public addresses or speeches by public figures are public domain although specific instantiations such as a newspaper transcript of a public speech may be copyrighted. If the raw transcript is reformatted and linked by the noder specifically for use on E2, it should be okay."

Writeup Title:[Dictionary of Mountain Bike Slang]
Author:[everyone]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: Y, See analysis below.
Original Author's Permission received?: Y
Quoted content less than 33%: NA
Compliance Assessment: y
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: Analysis & comments below. Additional info at http://tinyurl.com/32amf & http://tinyurl.com/3bej5.

Presumed Public Domain

I worked with other members of the CST_Group for awhile now to reach a verdict on the [Dictionary of Mountain Bike Slang], and it's myriad [NFN |definition writeups]. This node has an interesting history that challenges and explores our interpretation of the Fair Use rules, recapitulated briefly below.

In general, I don't like to lose good content. I've come to feel that every writeup nuked is a small failure, and every one saved is a success.  Given that approach, I propose the following analysis and review of the [Dictionary of Mountain Bike Slang].

History

The [Dictionary of Mountain Bike Slang] writeup is a derivative of a piece titled [Internet MTB Dictionary] (MounTain Bike) which was widely posted on the internet.  The MTB version was created from a lively thread the rec.bicycles.off-road Usenet group solicited by Tom Purvis in February 1995.  This thread was compiled by Doug Landauer &  Jim Frost, and was later expanded by Jerry Dunn, who used the discussion without permission in an LA Times article and later in a book about slang.  Mr. Dunn's pieces are both copyright protected, the original Usenet messages and the compilation by Landauer and Frost, do not appear to be explicitly copyrighted.

The E2 author [superdan2k] credits Landauer and Frost, and cites [Internet MTB Dictionary|their version] as a source.  The primary node contains a single writeup listing all the MTB terms as links.  "Definition" nodes and writeups appear to exist for each term (tho I haven't been exhaustive in checking this).  The Definition nodes each appear to have at least a single definition C&P from the MTB,  in many cases, these nodes also have other writeups that expand on the term and provide alternative definitions.

Analysis

Considered apart from copyright issues, the [Dictionary of Mountain Bike Slang] has considerable merit.  The terminology of mountain bikers overlaps that of surfers, skaters, skiers and other extreme sports to a large extent. The terms have an insidious way of creeping into the general vernacular and, in some cases losing track of their original meaning entirely.  For example, my friends and I were "Catching [Air]," on the motocross track when [Air Nike|Michael Jordan] was still a kid.

The unadorned factoid nature of the definition writeups is a neutral value in my book.  We sometimes prize fact nodes as a class, but trash the most succinct of them as "too short." If a brief definition is the only writeup in a node, and it's an accurate explanation of the term, then it has an intrinsic merit worthy of protection until a better candidate presents itself.  There is value in breadth as well as depth I believe.

The copyright status of this work is clouded at best.  I have written permission requests to both "compilers" of the [Internet MTB Dictionary] but have not, as of yet, received a reply.  I have some doubt as to the legal grounds on which Landauer and Frost could grant us permission to repost anyway, since they clearly didn't write most of the material themselves in the first place.  Jerry Dunn has apparently caused some ire among the original rec.bicycles.off-road Usenet group by publishing their work for profit under his own imprimateur.  The material posted on E2 cites MTB rather than Dunn's work, and doesn't appear to contain C&P text from Dunn's publications.

To remove the complication of having a fled noder at the root of all this mischief, I propose to remove [superdan2k]'s [Internet MTB Dictionary|their version] writeup and replace it with a short explanation and the properly cited Introduction to Landauer and Frost's MTB.  This will be followed by a list of the individual terms, linked to the existing writeups by [superdan2k] et. al.

I'd propose that this writeup pass the [CST_Group] Review for compliance under Public Domain rules, as interpreted in [E2 FAQ: Copyrighted Material] in the section on "UseNet postings..."  I will also add text explaining that anyone who feels they have ownership of any or all the materials need only contact the E2 Management to have it removed.

 Postscriptum: Bones, Lometa, Brawl, DatDaidDude, Arieh, Momomom & Chiisuta have been kind enough to review and comment on this approach. The Ayes have it and this is now officially [Policy|consensus].

Writeup Title:[Muro Saisei]
Author:[oceansleep]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: n
Original Author's Permission received?: n
Quoted content less than 33%: y, 11%
Compliance Assessment: Y
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2004.3.4 (CST_Group) (17.3 min) Orpheum says Hi. I was hoping for some help, with a wu my mentee has on her scratch pad. The wu is [Muro Saisei], and I'm particularly interested in the poem she is using. I'd love to give her the answer myself, but won't be able to give it the time for days. It's an awesome wu (I'm very proud!), and I don't want to delay its birth.
([oceansleep]) (1 s) [GrouchyOldMan] says re E2 Scratch Pad : Excellent work! I have been asked by orpheum to check this for copyright compliance . On the assumption that the translation itself is copyrighted, your writeup is compliant under Fair Use . Pls add the CST Approved tag and let us know when you post. Thanks, -gom

Writeup Title:[Won't Get Fooled Again]
Author:[TheDeadGuy]
Reviewer: [GrouchyOldMan]
Public domain?: n
Original Author's Permission received?: n
Quoted content less than 33%: y
Compliance Assessment: y
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes: 2004.3.3 [GrouchyOldMan] says Damnit Keith, you're not gonna believe this: It isn't compliant... The lyric quote is 286, max is 250 [as you know|AYK].
[TheDeadGuy] says So, I need to drop 36 words of lyric? That can be done. My concern is that is contains no original material.
[GrouchyOldMan] : Yeah, oddly enough, the Fair Use rules appear to support even wus that have no original content. In essence your choice of quotes represents "artistic expression," In fact this piece is an excellent example of the concept.

2004.03.06 at 13:56 [GrouchyOldMan] says I think this still needs a review: [momomom] says [Winter's Tale] is not compliant but could easily be made to be ... (the one by [dutchess])
2004.03.07 at 15:26 [Lometa] says Hello [dutchess]. The Content Salvage team brought this wonderful write up to my attention and I was wondering if you would please consider amending it to meet the recent E2 copyright changes under the sub heading “Copyrighted fiction and non-fiction.”?
2004.03.12 at 12:18 [dutchess] says Re: [Winter's Tale], and other book reviews of mine in general--I've been meaning to get to that, and haven't yet. School reports are due soon, so I doubt I'll do it this weekend. Perhaps, if it gets nuked, I could rework it sometime in the future? Thanks for the heads up; I don't *want* to be noncompliant, but it's just not been a priority in my life recently...

Writeup Title: [What the Thunder Said]
Author: [Lometa]
Reviewer: [momomom]

Writeup Title:[ Scarlet's Walk]
Author:[ Jallack]
Reviewer: [Lometa]
Public domain?: No.
Original Author's Permission received?:No.
Quoted content less than 33%: 29%
Compliance Assessment: Yes.
Review Request (w/timestamp) & Notes:
Review Request(Noder's /msg text): Jallak says Scarlet's Walk and Virginia are both CSt-compliant.
Notes: msged [Jallack] re [Scarlet's Walk] – “Hello there. You may want to add a little more content to meet the 33% requirement for copyright compliance. As the write up stands now the explicated content is 48%. I’m looking forward to reviewing it again. Let me know what you decide. [Lometa|lo]”
msged [Jallack] re [Virginia] “Hi it’s [Lomets|lo] again:) The explicated content of this write up is 50%. To meet copyright compliance the quoted content must be 33% or less. It’s a wonderful explication and I hope you’ll add more. I’ll be happy to take another look for CST approval. “
Update September 19, 2003. Hello Jallak, Just a note to let you know the deadline has been extended to the 22nd. The editors will probably remove non-compliant write-ups after that. Please know that you can always add more content and re submit them after an editor has previewed them on your scratch pad.
Update September 20, 2003:Hi Jallak, I did some double-checking with an editor in case I misunderstood the math and here is the formula we are using to determine copyright compliance for lyrics. The quoted content must be less than 33%. So it’s (Quoted Material word count / Total write-up word count) *100 = a percentage. For [Scarlet’s Walk] there are 218 words in the lyrics and 455 words of original content. 218/455 =.479 *100 = 48% . [Virginia] is 228/446=.511 *100= 51% I hope that helps.
[Jallak] says Okay, so what you mean is its actuall quoted/non-quoted*100. So the original content should actually be 75% of total word count. Gotcha. Thanks.
msged [Jallack] re [Scarlet's Walk]- Thanks for getting these updated! They have been re evaluated and passed with flying colors. You may add the hardlink [CST Approved] .
